title: John Jeffrey pushed by Six Nations to become new World Rugby chairman
text:
Six Nations push for Jeffrey... not Pichot

The great and the not-so-good of the rugby world will descend on Tokyo later this month for World Rugby’s general assembly.

The blazer brigade will get five-star treatment in what insiders say will be an extremely ‘political’ gathering. Members from all 124 unions will check in at the city’s swanky ANA Intercontinental Hotel, which can cost up to £700 per night.

There is growing resentment towards the self-interested Six Nations. A new World Rugby chairman will be elected next May and tradition dictates that the vice-chairman, in this case Gus Pichot, takes over.

Tradition dictates that Gus Pichot will take over as the new World Rugby chairman next May

But Pichot is a fierce defender of tier-two nations and conservative European heavyweights are worried that he could upset the archaic status quo. One Gain Line source indicated there could be a northern hemisphere push for former Scotland flanker John Jeffrey — a more protectionist option — to be given the role.

With hotels charging upwards of £3 to wash a pair of socks, Scotland have Darcy Graham to thank for bringing down their steep laundry bill. As the youngest player, the 22-year-old winger was responsible for ironing senior players’ shirts before their welcome ceremony in Japan.

All Blacks keep it tasty

As well as winning the battle on the pitch, the All Blacks are also leading the way off it.

Teams are expected to foot the bill for any media refreshments at press conferences.

Most — including cash-strapped England – have been offering no food or drink. But the Kiwis have been laying on spreads including fresh sashimi, tempura, samosas, pavlovas and a selection of drinks.

Unsurprisingly, the world champions have been dominating the airwaves and column inches in Japan. Irrespective of their culinary offerings, it feels like England so far missed an open goal to tap into a new Asian market.

30m Japanese tune in

Japanese broadcasters are expecting their biggest rugby TV audience of all time for the hosts’ pool showdown with Scotland next Sunday. Before the World Cup, the record TV audience was 19.5million for France’s semi-final defeat by England in 2007. That figure was smashed by more than 10m last week when Japan beat Ireland. Now, more than 30m are forecast to tune in as Japan battle to make the last eight.

Japanese broadcasters are expecting their biggest rugby TV audience of all time next Sunday

The Gain Line’s brief chat with a group of England players in a naked Onsen Spa made its way into The Japan Times! Joe Marler called out your columnist at a press conference for ‘offending local culture’ by wearing swimming shorts in the naturist hot pools. His joke was lost in translation though and the outspoken prop was portrayed as an international diplomat!

authors: Nik Simon For The Mail On Sunday
